body.p: offers a feature that provides the ability for authoring teams to edit and review content concurrently. You can share your editing session and then send its URL to other collaborators and then you and your colleagues can edit and review the same document simultaneously.

To initiate a shared editing session, use the Share Session toolbar button. This opens the first window of the Share Editing Session dialog box. It provides some information, and after clicking Share, the second window of the dialog box is displayed.

fig.title: Share Editing Session Dialog Box (Second Window)

body.p: This is where you can retrieve a URL that you can send to other collaborators. While the session is shared, other users can join and each user can see the changes made by others, as well as their own modifications, in real-time. The person who originally shared the session is the only one who can save the document and the concurrent editing session continues as long as that person keeps the document open.The Share Session action is only present, by default, for some of the built-in connectors (Git and WebDAV).

ul.li: The Edit as XML action (used for switching to the text-based mode) is not available in concurrent editing mode.
Change tracking cannot be enabled during concurrent editing mode. Tracked changes that are already present in the document when the concurrent editing session is created are still preserved.
The Mark as Done and Reply actions (for comments) are removed during concurrent editing sessions.
The Edit Topic Content option that is usually available from the DITA Map Display Mode drop-down menu is not available in concurrent editing sessions.
Changes made prior to the session being shared cannot be undone.
This feature is currently in an experimental BETA stage so it is possible to encounter stability and performance issues that will be solved in future releases.
